<P class="p204 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(C)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">the location, specified in Annex E, Appendix 1, where the conduct of the pre flight inspection is desired and the date and start time of such pre flight inspection in accordance with the provisions of Annex F;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p204 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(D)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft58">the mode of transport and, if applicable, type and model of the transport aircraft used to travel to the point of entry in the event that the observation aircraft used for the observation flight is provided by the observed Party;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p205 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(E)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft43">the diplomatic clearance number for the observation flight or for the flight of the transport aircraft used to bring the personnel in and out of the territory of the observed Party to conduct an observation flight;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p204 ft14"><SPAN class="ft3">(F)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft42">the identification of the observation aircraft, as specified in Annex C;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p206 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(G)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft58">the approximate observation flight distance; and</SPAN></P>
<P class="p207 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(H)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft58">the names of the personnel, their gender, date and place of birth, passport number and issuing State Party, and their function.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p208 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">6.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft40">The observed Party that is notified in accordance with paragraph 5 of this Section shall acknowledge receipt of the notification within 24 hours. In the event that the observed Party exercises its right to provide the observation aircraft, the acknowledgement shall include the information about the observation aircraft specified in paragraph 5, subparagraph</SPAN></P>
<P class="p209 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">(F)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft43">of this Section. The observing Party shall be permitted to arrive at the point of entry at the estimated time of arrival as notified in accordance with paragraph 5 of this Section. The estimated time of departure for the flight from the point of entry to the Open Skies airfield where the observation flight shall commence and the location, the date and the start time of the </SPAN><NOBR>pre-flight</NOBR> inspection shall be subject to confirmation by the observed Party.</P>
<P class="p210 ft14"><SPAN class="ft5">7.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft42">Personnel of the observing Party may include personnel designated pursuant to Article XIII by other States Parties.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p203 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">8.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft7">The observing Party, when notifying the observed Party in accordance with paragraph 5 of this Section, shall simultaneously notify all other States Parties of its intention to conduct the observation flight.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p203 ft14"><SPAN class="ft5">9.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft41">The period from the estimated time of arrival at the point of entry until completion of the observation flight shall not exceed 96 hours, un-</SPAN></P>
<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t9">
<TR>
	<TD class="tr4 td36"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">less otherwise agreed. In the event that the observed Party requests a de-</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD rowspan=2 class="tr2 td37"><SPAN class="p13 ft3">49</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr17 td36"><SPAN class="p3 ft33">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_50">


<DIV>
<DIV id="id_1">
<P class="p211 ft3">monstration flight pursuant to Annex F to the Treaty, it shall extend the <NOBR>96-hour</NOBR> period pursuant to Annex F, Section III, paragraph 4, if additional time is required by the observing Party for the unrestricted execution of the mission plan.</P>
<P class="p41 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">10.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft40">Upon arrival of the observation aircraft at the point of entry, the observed Party shall inspect the covers for sensor apertures or other devices that inhibit the operation of sensors to confirm that they are in their proper position pursuant to Annex E, unless otherwise agreed by all States Parties involved.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p182 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">11.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft43">In the event that the observation aircraft is provided by the observing Party, upon the arrival of the observation aircraft at the point of entry or at the Open Skies airfield where the observation flight commences, the observed Party shall have the right to carry out the </SPAN><NOBR>pre-flight</NOBR> inspection pursuant to Annex F, Section I. In the event that, in accordance with paragraph 1 of this Section, an observation aircraft is provided by the observed Party, the observing Party shall have the right to carry out the <NOBR>pre-flight</NOBR> inspection of sensors pursuant to Annex F, Section II. Un- less otherwise agreed, such inspections shall terminate no less than four hours prior to the scheduled commencement of the observation flight set forth in the flight plan.</P>
<P class="p40 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">12.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft7">The observing Party shall ensure that its flight crew includes at least one individual who has the necessary linguistic ability to communicate freely with the personnel of the observed Party and its air traffic control authorities in the language or languages notified by the observed Party in accordance with paragraph 4 of this Section.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p40 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">13.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">The observed Party shall provide the flight crew, upon its arrival at the point of entry or at the Open Skies airfield where the observation flight commences, with the most recent weather forecast and air navigation information and information on flight safety, including Notices to Airmen. Updates of such information shall be provided as requested. In- strument procedures, and information about alternate airfields along the flight route, shall be provided upon approval of the mission plan in accordance with the requirements of Section II of this Article.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p182 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">14.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft7">While conducting observation flights pursuant to this Treaty, all observation aircraft shall be operated in accordance with the provisions of this Treaty and in accordance with the approved flight plan. Without prejudice to the provisions of Section II, paragraph 2 of this Article, observation flights shall also be conducted in compliance with:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p212 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(A)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">published ICAO standards and recommended practices; and</SPAN></P>
<P class="p181 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(B)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">published national air traffic control rules, procedures and guidelines on flight safety of the State Party whose territory is being overflown.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p164 ft31"><SPAN class="ft5">15.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft61">Observation flights shall take priority over any regular air traffic. The observed Party shall ensure that its air traffic control authorities facilitate the conduct of observation flights in accordance with this Treaty.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p41 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">16.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft43">On board the aircraft the </SPAN><NOBR>pilot-in-command</NOBR> shall be the sole authority for the safe conduct of the flight and shall be responsible for the execution of the flight plan.</P>
<P class="p129 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">17.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">The observed Party shall provide:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p206 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(A)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft58">a calibration target suitable for confirming the capability of sen-</SPAN></P>
<P class="p202 ft3">sors in accordance with the procedures set forth in Annex D,</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="id_2">
<P class="p12 ft3">Prop. 2001/02:157</P>
<P class="p12 ft3">Bilaga 6</P>
<P class="p118 ft3">50</P>
</DIV>
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_51">


<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t13">
<TR>
	<TD class="tr9 td12"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">Section III to this Treaty, to be overflown during the demonstra-</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr9 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft5">Prop. 2001/02:157</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr6 td12"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">tion flight or the observation flight upon the request of either</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr6 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">Bilaga 6</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr6 td12"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">Party, for each sensor that is to be used during the observation</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr6 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr6 td12"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">flight. The calibration target shall be located in the vicinity of</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr6 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr7 td12"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">the airfield at which the <NOBR>pre-flight</NOBR> inspection is conducted pur-</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr7 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr6 td12"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">suant to Annex F to this Treaty;</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr6 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P class="p174 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(B)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">customary commercial aircraft fuelling and servicing for the observation aircraft or transport aircraft at the point of entry, at the Open Skies airfield, at any refuelling airfield, and at the point of exit specified in the flight plan, according to the specifications that are published about the designated airfield;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p174 ft14"><SPAN class="ft3">(C)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft46">meals and the use of accommodation for the personnel of the observing Party; and</SPAN></P>
<P class="p174 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(D)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft58">upon the request of the observing Party, further services, as may be agreed upon between the observing and observed Parties, to facilitate the conduct of the observation flight.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">18.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft40">All costs involved in the conduct of the observation flight, including the costs of the recording media and the processing of the data collected by sensors, shall be reimbursed in accordance with Annex L, Section I, paragraph 9 to this Treaty.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">19.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft43">Prior to the departure of the observation aircraft from the point of exit, the observed Party shall confirm that the covers for sensor apertures or other devices that inhibit the operation of sensors are in their proper position pursuant to Annex E to this Treaty.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">20.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft43">Unless otherwise agreed, the observing Party shall depart from the point of exit no later than 24 hours following completion of the observation flight, unless weather conditions or the airworthiness of the observation aircraft or transport aircraft do not permit, in which case the flight shall commence as soon as practicable.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">21.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft43">The observing Party shall compile a mission report of the observation flight using the appropriate format developed by the Open Skies Consultative Commission. The mission report shall contain pertinent data on the date and time of the observation flight, its route and profile, weather conditions, time and location of each observation period for each sensor, the approximate amount of data collected by sensors, and the result of inspection of covers for sensor apertures or other devices that inhibit the operation of sensors in accordance with Article VII and Annex E. The mission report shall be signed by the observing and observed Parties at the point of exit and shall be provided by the observing Party to all other States Parties within seven days after departure of the observing Party from the point of exit.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p213 ft3">SECTION II. REQUIREMENTS FOR MISSION PLANNING</P>
<P class="p214 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft7">Unless otherwise agreed, the observing Party shall, after arrival at the Open Skies airfield, submit to the observed Party a mission plan for the proposed observation flight that meets the requirements of paragraphs 2 and 4 of this Section.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft40">The mission plan may provide for an observation flight that allows for the observation of any point on the entire territory of the observed</SPAN></P>
<P class="p215 ft3">51</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_52">


<DIV>
<DIV id="id_1">
<P class="p216 ft5">Party, including areas designated by the observed Party as hazardous airspace in the source specified in Annex I. The flight path of an observation aircraft shall not be closer than, but shall be allowed up to, ten kilometres from the border with an adjacent State that is not a State Party.</P>
<P class="p164 ft5"><SPAN class="ft5">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft8">The mission plan may provide that the Open Skies airfield where the observation flight terminates, as well as the point of exit, may be different from the Open Skies airfield where the observation flight commences or the point of entry. The mission plan shall specify, if applicable, the commencement time of the observation flight, the desired time and place of planned refuelling stops or rest periods, and the time of continuation of the observation flight after a refuelling stop or rest period within the </SPAN><NOBR>96-hour</NOBR> period specified in Section I, paragraph 9 of this Article.</P>
<P class="p182 ft14"><SPAN class="ft5">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft42">The mission plan shall include all information necessary to file the flight plan and shall provide that:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p181 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(A)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft58">the observation flight does not exceed the relevant maximum flight distance as set forth in Annex A, Section I;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p181 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(B)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">the route and profile of the observation flight satisfies observation flight safety conditions in conformity with ICAO standards and recommended practices, taking into account existing differences in national flight rules, without prejudice to the provisions of paragraph 2 of this Section;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p181 ft14"><SPAN class="ft3">(C)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft46">the mission plan takes into account information on hazardous airspace, as provided in accordance with Annex I;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p181 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(D)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft58">the height above ground level of the observation aircraft does not permit the observing Party to exceed the limitation on ground resolution for each sensor, as set forth in Article IV, paragraph 2;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p206 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(E)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft43">the estimated time of commencement of the observation flight</SPAN></P>
<P class="p217 ft3">shall be no less than 24 hours after the submission of the mission plan, unless otherwise agreed;</P>
<P class="p181 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(F)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft40">the observation aircraft flies a direct route between the coordinates or navigation fixes designated in the mission plan in the declared sequence; and</SPAN></P>
<P class="p181 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(G)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft58">the flight path does not intersect at the same point more than once, unless otherwise agreed, and the observation aircraft does not circle around a single point, unless otherwise agreed. The provisions of this subparagraph do not apply for the purposes of taking off, flying over calibration targets, or landing by the observation aircraft.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p41 ft14"><SPAN class="ft5">5.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft44">In the event that the mission plan filed by the observing Party provides for flights through hazardous airspace, the observed Party shall:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p206 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(A)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft58">specify the hazard to the observation aircraft;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p218 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(B)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">facilitate the conduct of the observation flight by </SPAN><NOBR>co-ordination</NOBR> or suppression of the activity specified pursuant to subparagraph (A) of this paragraph; or</P>
<P class="p206 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(C)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">propose an alternative flight altitude, route, or time.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p164 ft5"><SPAN class="ft5">6.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft62">No later than four hours after submission of the mission plan, the observed Party shall accept the mission plan or propose changes to it in accordance with Article VIII, Section I, paragraph 4 and paragraph 5 of this Section. Such changes shall not preclude observation of any point on</SPAN></P>
<P class="p219 ft3">the entire territory of the observed Party, including areas designated by</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="id_2">
<P class="p12 ft3">Prop. 2001/02:157</P>
<P class="p12 ft3">Bilaga 6</P>
<P class="p118 ft3">52</P>
</DIV>
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_53">


<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t5">
<TR>
	<TD class="tr9 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">the observed Party as hazardous airspace in the source specified in An-</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr9 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft5">Prop. 2001/02:157</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr6 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">nex I to this Treaty. Upon agreement, the mission plan shall be signed by</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr6 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">Bilaga 6</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr6 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">the observing and observed Parties. In the event that the Parties do not</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr6 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr6 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">reach agreement on the mission plan within eight hours of the submission</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr6 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr7 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">of the original mission plan, the observing Party shall have the right to</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr7 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr6 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">decline to conduct the observation flight in accordance with the provi-</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr6 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr6 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">sions of Article VIII of this Treaty.</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr6 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P class="p22 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">7.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft40">If the planned route of the observation flight approaches the border of other States Parties or other States, the observed Party may notify that State or those States of the estimated route, date and time of the observation flight.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p85 ft14"><SPAN class="ft5">8.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft44">On the basis of the agreed mission plan the State Party providing the observation aircraft shall, in </SPAN><NOBR>co-ordination</NOBR> with the other State Party, file the flight plan immediately, which shall have the content specified in Annex 2 to the Convention on International Civil Aviation and shall be in the format specified by ICAO Document No. <NOBR>4444-RAC/501/12,</NOBR> "Ru- les of the Air and Air Traffic Services", as revised or amended.</P>
<P class="p83 ft3">SECTION III. SPECIAL PROVISIONS</P>
<P class="p220 ft5"><SPAN class="ft5">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft62">In the event that the observation aircraft is provided by the observing Party, the observed Party shall have the right to have on board the observation aircraft two flight monitors and one interpreter, in addition to one flight monitor for each sensor control station on board the observation aircraft, unless otherwise agreed. Flight monitors and interpreters shall have the rights and obligations specified in Annex G to this Treaty.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p24 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft43">Notwithstanding paragraph 1 of this Section, in the event that an observing Party uses an observation aircraft which has a maximum </SPAN><NOBR>take-off</NOBR> gross weight of no more than 35,000 kilograms for an observation flight distance of no more than 1,500 kilometres as notified in accordance with Section I, paragraph 5, subparagraph (G) of this Article, it shall be obliged to accept only two flight monitors and one interpreter on board the observation aircraft, unless otherwise agreed.</P>
<P class="p23 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft43">In the event that the observation aircraft is provided by the observed Party, the observed Party shall permit the personnel of the observing Party to travel to the point of entry of the observed Party in the most expeditious manner. The personnel of the observing Party may elect to travel to the point of entry using ground, sea, or air transportation, including transportation by an aircraft owned by any State Party. Procedures regarding such travel are set forth in Annex E to this Treaty.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p24 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft43">In the event that the observation aircraft is provided by the observed Party, the observing Party shall have the right to have on board the observation aircraft two flight representatives and one interpreter, in addition to one flight representative for each sensor control station on the aircraft, unless otherwise agreed. Flight representatives and interpreters shall have the rights and obligations set forth in Annex G to this Treaty.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">5.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft40">In the event that the observing State Party provides an observation aircraft designated by a State Party other than the observing or observed Party, the observing Party shall have the right to have on board the observation aircraft two representatives and one interpreter, in addition to</SPAN></P>
<P class="p134 ft3">53</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_54">


<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t5">
<TR>
	<TD class="tr9 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">one representative for each sensor control station on the aircraft, unless</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr9 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft5">Prop. 2001/02:157</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr6 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">otherwise agreed. In this case, the provisions on flight monitors set forth</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr6 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">Bilaga 6</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr6 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">in paragraph 1 of this Section shall also apply. Representatives and inter-</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr6 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr6 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">preters shall have the rights and obligations set forth in Annex G to this</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr6 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr8 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">Treaty.</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr8 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P class="p221 ft24">Article VII</P>
<P class="p222 ft56">TRANSIT FLIGHTS</P>
<P class="p223 ft14"><SPAN class="ft5">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft42">Transit flights conducted by an observing Party to and from the territory of an observed Party for the purposes of this Treaty shall originate on the territory of the observing Party or of another State Party.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p85 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft43">Each State Party shall accept transit flights. Such transit flights shall be conducted along internationally recognized Air Traffic Services routes, unless otherwise agreed by the States Parties involved, and in accordance with the instructions of the national air traffic control authorities of each State Party whose airspace is transited. The observing Party shall notify each State Party whose airspace is to be transited at the same time that it notifies the observed Party in accordance with Article VI.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft14"><SPAN class="ft5">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft49">The operation of sensors on an observation aircraft during transit flights is prohibited. In the event that, during the transit flight, the observation aircraft lands on the territory of a State Party, that State Party shall, upon landing and prior to departure, inspect the covers of sensor apertures or other devices that inhibit the operation of sensors to confirm that they are in their proper position.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p224 ft24">Article VIII</P>
<P class="p225 ft56">PROHIBITIONS, DEVIATIONS FROM FLIGHT PLANS AND</P>
<P class="p49 ft56">EMERGENCY SITUATIONS</P>
<P class="p226 ft3">SECTION I. PROHIBITION OF OBSERVATION FLIGHTS AND</P>
<P class="p227 ft3">CHANGES TO MISSION PLANS</P>
<P class="p214 ft14"><SPAN class="ft5">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft41">The observed Party shall have the right to prohibit an observation flight that is not in compliance with the provisions of this Treaty.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft7">The observed Party shall have the right to prohibit an observation flight prior to its commencement in the event that the observing Party fails to arrive at the point of entry within 24 hours after the estimated time of arrival specified in the notification provided in accordance with Article VI, Section I, paragraph 5, unless otherwise agreed between the States Parties involved.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft7">In the event that an observed State Party prohibits an observation flight pursuant to this Article or Annex F, it shall immediately state the facts for the prohibition in the mission plan. Within seven days the observed Party shall provide to all States Parties, through diplomatic channels, a written explanation for this prohibition in the mission report provided pursuant to Article VI, Section I, paragraph 21. An observation</SPAN></P>
<P class="p228 ft3">54</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_55">


<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t5">
<TR>
	<TD class="tr9 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">flight that has been prohibited shall not be counted against the quota of</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr9 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft5">Prop. 2001/02:157</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr7 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">either State Party.</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr7 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">Bilaga 6</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P class="p22 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft7">The observed Party shall have the right to propose changes to the mission plan as a result of any of the following circumstances:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p175 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(A)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft58">the weather conditions affect flight safety;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p174 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(B)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">the status of the Open Skies airfield to be used, alternate airfields, or refuelling airfields prevents their use; or</SPAN></P>
<P class="p174 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(C)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">the mission plan is inconsistent with Article VI, Section II, paragraphs 2 and 4.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">5.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft7">In the event that the observing Party disagrees with the proposed changes to the mission plan, it shall have the right to submit alternatives to the proposed changes. In the event that agreement on a mission plan is not reached within eight hours of the submission of the original mission plan, and if the observing Party considers the changes to the mission plan to be prejudicial to its rights under this Treaty with respect to the conduct of the observation flight, the observing Party shall have the right to decline to conduct the observation flight, which shall not be recorded against the quota of either State Party.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">6.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft43">In the event that an observing Party declines to conduct an observation flight pursuant to this Article or Annex F, it shall immediately provide an explanation of its decision in the mission plan prior to the departure of the observing Party. Within seven days after departure of the observing Party, the observing Party shall provide to all other States Parties, through diplomatic channels, a written explanation for this decision in the mission report provided pursuant to Article VI, Section I, paragraph 21.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p213 ft3">SECTION II. DEVIATIONS FROM THE FLIGHT PLAN</P>
<P class="p214 ft14"><SPAN class="ft5">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft42">Deviations from the flight plan shall be permitted during the observation flight if necessitated by:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p175 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(A)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft58">weather conditions affecting flight safety;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p175 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(B)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">technical difficulties relating to the observation aircraft;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p175 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(C)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">a medical emergency of any person on board; or</SPAN></P>
<P class="p174 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(D)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft58">air traffic control instructions related to circumstances brought about by force majeure.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft48">In addition, if weather conditions prevent effective use of optical sensors and </SPAN><NOBR>infra-red</NOBR> <NOBR>line-scanning</NOBR> devices, deviations shall be permitted, provided that:</P>
<P class="p175 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(A)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft58">flight safety requirements are met;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p174 ft14"><SPAN class="ft3">(B)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft46">in cases where national rules so require, permission is granted by air traffic control authorities; and</SPAN></P>
<P class="p174 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(C)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">the performance of the sensors does not exceed the capabilities specified in Article IV, paragraph 2, unless otherwise agreed.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p85 ft63"><SPAN class="ft63">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft64">The observed Party shall have the right to prohibit the use of a particular sensor during a deviation that brings the observation aircraft below the minimum height above ground level for operating that particular sensor, in accordance with the limitation on ground resolution specified in Article IV, paragraph 2. In the event that a deviation requires the observation aircraft to alter its flight path by more than 50 kilometres from the</SPAN></P>
<P class="p229 ft3">55</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_56">


<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t5">
<TR>
	<TD class="tr9 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">flight path specified in the flight plan, the observed Party shall have the</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr9 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft5">Prop. 2001/02:157</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr6 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">right to prohibit the use of all the sensors installed on the observation</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr6 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">Bilaga 6</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr7 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">aircraft beyond that <NOBR>50-kilometre</NOBR> limit.</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr7 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P class="p22 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft7">The observing Party shall have the right to curtail an observation flight during its execution in the event of sensor malfunction. The pilot- </SPAN><NOBR>in-command</NOBR> shall have the right to curtail an observation flight in the event of technical difficulties affecting the safety of the observation aircraft.</P>
<P class="p22 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">5.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft40">In the event that a deviation from the flight plan permitted by paragraph 1 of this Section results in curtailment of the observation flight, or a curtailment occurs in accordance with paragraph 4 of this Section, an observation flight shall be counted against the quotas of both States Parties, unless the curtailment is due to:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p174 ft14"><SPAN class="ft3">(A)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft59">sensor malfunction on an observation aircraft provided by the observed Party;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p174 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(B)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">technical difficulties relating to the observation aircraft provided by the observed Party;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p174 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(C)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">a medical emergency of a member of the flight crew of the observed Party or of flight monitors; or</SPAN></P>
<P class="p174 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(D)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft58">air traffic control instructions related to circumstances brought about by force majeure.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p230 ft3">In such cases the observing Party shall have the right to decide whether to count it against the quotas of both States Parties.</P>
<P class="p22 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">6.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft40">The data collected by the sensors shall be retained by the observing Party only if the observation flight is counted against the quotas of both States Parties.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">7.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft40">In the event that a deviation is made from the flight plan, the pilot- </SPAN><NOBR>in-command</NOBR> shall take action in accordance with the published national flight regulations of the observed Party. Once the factors leading to the deviation have ceased to exist, the observation aircraft may, with the permission of the air traffic control authorities, continue the observation flight in accordance with the flight plan. The additional flight distance of the observation aircraft due to the deviation shall not count against the maximum flight distance.</P>
<P class="p22 ft14"><SPAN class="ft5">8.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft49">Personnel of both States Parties on board the observation aircraft shall be immediately informed of all deviations from the flight plan.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft14"><SPAN class="ft5">9.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft41">Additional expenses resulting from provisions of this Article shall be reimbursed in accordance with Annex L, Section I, paragraph 9 to this Treaty.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p165 ft3">SECTION III. EMERGENCY SITUATIONS</P>
<P class="p214 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft65">In the event that an emergency situation arises, the </SPAN><NOBR>pilot-in-</NOBR> command shall be guided by "Procedures for Air Navigation Services – Rules of the Air and Air Traffic Services", ICAO Document No. 4444- RAC/501/12, as revised or amended, the national flight regulations of the observed Party, and the flight operation manual of the observation aircraft.</P>
<P class="p85 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft40">Each observation aircraft declaring an emergency shall be accorded the full range of distress and navigational facilities of the observed Party</SPAN></P>
<P class="p215 ft3">56</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_57">


<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t5">
<TR>
	<TD class="tr9 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">in order to ensure the most expeditious recovery of the aircraft to the nea-</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr9 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft5">Prop. 2001/02:157</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr7 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">rest suitable airfield.</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr7 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">Bilaga 6</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P class="p22 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft40">In the event of an aviation accident involving the observation aircraft on the territory of the observed Party, search and rescue operations shall be conducted by the observed Party in accordance with its own regulations and procedures for such operations.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft40">Investigation of an aviation accident or incident involving an observation aircraft shall be conducted by the observed Party, with the participation of the observing Party, in accordance with the ICAO recommendations set forth in Annex 13 to the Convention on International Civil Aviation ("Investigation of Aviation Accidents") as revised or amended and in accordance with the national regulations of the observed Party.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft14"><SPAN class="ft5">5.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft41">In the event that the observation aircraft is not registered with the observed Party, at the conclusion of the investigation all wreckage and debris of the observation aircraft and sensors, if found and recovered, shall be returned to the observing Party or to the Party to which the aircraft belongs, if so requested.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p231 ft24">Article IX</P>
<P class="p232 ft56">SENSOR OUTPUT FROM OBSERVATION FLIGHTS</P>
<P class="p89 ft3">SECTION I. GENERAL PROVISIONS</P>
<P class="p233 ft14">1. For the purposes of recording data collected by sensors during observation flights, the following recording media shall be used:</P>
<P class="p174 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(A)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft58">in the case of optical panoramic and framing cameras, black and white photographic film;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p175 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(B)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">in the case of video cameras, magnetic tape;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p174 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(C)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">in the case of </SPAN><NOBR>infra-red</NOBR> <NOBR>line-scanning</NOBR> devices, black and white photographic film or magnetic tape; and</P>
<P class="p174 ft14"><SPAN class="ft3">(D)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft59">in the case of </SPAN><NOBR>sideways-looking</NOBR> synthetic aperture radar, magnetic tape.</P>
<P class="p22 ft3">The agreed format in which such data is to be recorded and exchanged on other recording media shall be decided within the Open Skies Consultative Commission during the period of provisional application of this Treaty.</P>
<P class="p22 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft43">Data collected by sensors during observation flights shall remain on board the observation aircraft until completion of the observation flight. The transmission of data collected by sensors from the observation aircraft during the observation flight is prohibited.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft40">Each roll of photographic film and cassette or reel of magnetic tape used to collect data by a sensor during an observation flight shall be placed in a container and sealed in the presence of the States Parties as soon as is practicable after it has been removed from the sensor.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft14"><SPAN class="ft5">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft41">Data collected by sensors during observation flights shall be made available to States Parties in accordance with the provisions of this Article and shall be used exclusively for the attainment of the purposes of this Treaty.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p139 ft3">57</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_58">


<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t5">
<TR>
	<TD class="tr9 td18"><SPAN class="p75 ft3">5. In the event that, on the basis of data provided pursuant to Annex B,</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr9 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft5">Prop. 2001/02:157</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr6 td18"><SPAN class="p75 ft3">Section I to this Treaty, a data recording medium to be used by a State</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr6 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">Bilaga 6</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr6 td18"><SPAN class="p75 ft3">Party during an observation flight is incompatible with the equipment of</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr6 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr6 td18"><SPAN class="p75 ft3">another State Party for handling that data recording medium, the States</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr6 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr7 td18"><SPAN class="p75 ft3">Parties involved shall establish procedures to ensure that all data collec-</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr7 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr6 td18"><SPAN class="p75 ft3">ted during observation flights can be handled, in terms of processing,</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr6 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr8 td18"><SPAN class="p234 ft5">duplication and storage, by them.</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr8 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P class="p235 ft3">SECTION II. OUTPUT FROM SENSORS THAT USE PHOTO-</P>
<P class="p49 ft3">GRAPHIC FILM</P>
<P class="p193 ft14"><SPAN class="ft5">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft42">In the event that output from duplicate optical cameras is to be exchanged, the cameras, film and film processing shall be of an identical type.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p85 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft43">Provided that the data collected by a single optical camera is subject to exchange, the States Parties shall consider, within the Open Skies Consultative Commission during the period of provisional application of this Treaty, the issue of whether the responsibility for the development of the original film negative shall be borne by the observing Party or by the State Party providing the observation aircraft. The State Party developing the original film negative shall be responsible for the quality of processing the original negative film and producing the duplicate positive or negative. In the event that States Parties agree that the film used during the observation flight conducted on an observation aircraft provided by the observed Party shall be processed by the observing Party, the observed Party shall bear no responsibility for the quality of the processing of the original negative film.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p88 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">All the film used during the observation flight shall be developed:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p174 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(A)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft58">in the event that the original film negative is developed at a film processing facility arranged for by the observed Party, no later than three days, unless otherwise agreed, after the arrival of the observation aircraft at the point of exit; or</SPAN></P>
<P class="p236 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(B)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">in the event that the original film negative is developed at a film processing facility arranged for by the observing Party, no later than ten days after the departure of the observation aircraft from the territory of the observed Party.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p23 ft5"><SPAN class="ft5">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft8">The State Party that is developing the original film negative shall be obliged to accept at the film processing facility up to two officials from the other State Party to monitor the unsealing of the film cassette or container and each step in the storage, processing, duplication and handling of the original film negative, in accordance with the provisions of Annex K, Section II to this Treaty. The State Party monitoring the film processing and duplication shall have the right to designate such officials from among its nationals present on the territory on which the film processing facility arranged for by the other State Party is located, provided that such individuals are on the list of designated personnel in accordance with Article XIII, Section I of this Treaty. The State Party developing the film shall assist the officials of the other State Party in their functions provided for in this paragraph to the maximum extent possible.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p237 ft3">58</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_59">


<DIV>
<DIV id="id_1">
<P class="p41 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">5.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft40">Upon completion of an observation flight, the State Party that is to develop the original film negative shall attach a </SPAN><NOBR>21-step</NOBR> sensitometric test strip of the same film type used during the observation flight or shall expose a <NOBR>21-step</NOBR> optical wedge onto the leader or trailer of each roll of original film negative used during the observation flight. After the original film negative has been processed and duplicate film negative or positive has been produced, the States Parties shall assess the image quality of the <NOBR>21-step</NOBR> sensitometric test strips or images of the <NOBR>21-step</NOBR> optical wedge against the characteristics provided for that type of original film negative or duplicate film negative or positive in accordance with the provisions of Annex K, Section I to this Treaty.</P>
<P class="p238 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">6.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">In the event that only one original film negative is developed:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p180 ft14"><SPAN class="ft3">(A)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft59">the observing Party shall have the right to retain or receive the original film negative; and</SPAN></P>
<P class="p181 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(B)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">the observed Party shall have the right to select and receive a complete first generation duplicate or part thereof, either positive or negative, of the original film negative. Unless otherwise agreed, such duplicate shall be:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p239 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">(1)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft40">of the same format and film size as the original film negati-</SPAN></P>
<P class="p239 ft3">ve;</P>
<P class="p240 ft14"><SPAN class="ft5">(2)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft44">produced immediately after development of the original film negative; and</SPAN></P>
<P class="p240 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">(3)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft40">provided to the officials of the observed Party immediately after the duplicate has been produced.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p129 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">7.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">In the event that two original film negatives are developed:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p181 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(A)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft58">if the observation aircraft is provided by the observing Party, the observed Party shall have the right, at the completion of the observation flight, to select either of the two original film negatives, and the original film negative not selected shall be retained by the observing Party; or</SPAN></P>
<P class="p181 ft14"><SPAN class="ft3">(B)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft46">if the observation aircraft is provided by the observed Party, the observing Party shall have the right to select either of the original film negatives, and the original film negative not selected shall be retained by the observed Party.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p241 ft10">SECTION III. OUTPUT FROM SENSORS THAT USE OTHER RE- CORDING MEDIA</P>
<P class="p242 ft14"><SPAN class="ft5">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft42">The State Party that provides the observation aircraft shall record at least one original set of data collected by sensors using other recording media.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p129 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">In the event that only one original set is made:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p181 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(A)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft58">if the observation aircraft is provided by the observing Party, the observing Party shall have the right to retain the original set and the observed Party shall have the right to receive a first generation duplicate copy; or</SPAN></P>
<P class="p181 ft14"><SPAN class="ft3">(B)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft46">if the observation aircraft is provided by the observed Party, the observing Party shall have the right to receive the original set and the observed Party shall have the right to receive a first generation duplicate copy.</SPAN></P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="id_2">
<P class="p12 ft3">Prop. 2001/02:157</P>
<P class="p12 ft3">Bilaga 6</P>
<P class="p118 ft3">59</P>
</DIV>
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_60">


<DIV>
<DIV id="id_1">
<P class="p129 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">In the event that two original sets are made:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p181 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(A)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft58">if the observation aircraft is provided by the observing Party, the observed Party shall have the right, at the completion of the observation flight, to select either of the two sets of recording media, and the set not selected shall be retained by the observing Party; or</SPAN></P>
<P class="p181 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(B)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">if the observation aircraft is provided by the observed Party, the observing Party shall have the right to select either of the two sets of recording media, and the set not selected shall be retained by the observed Party.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p40 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft7">In the event that the observation aircraft is provided by the observing Party, the observed Party shall have the right to receive the data collected by a </SPAN><NOBR>sideways-looking</NOBR> synthetic aperture radar in the form of either initial phase information or a radar image, at its choice.</P>
<P class="p40 ft14"><SPAN class="ft5">5.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft44">In the event that the observation aircraft is provided by the observed Party, the observing Party shall have the right to receive the data collected by a </SPAN><NOBR>sideways-looking</NOBR> synthetic aperture radar in the form of either initial phase information or a radar image, at its choice.</P>
<P class="p55 ft3">SECTION IV. ACCESS TO SENSOR OUTPUT</P>
<P class="p133 ft3">Each State Party shall have the right to request and receive from the observing Party copies of data collected by sensors during an observation flight. Such copies shall be in the form of first generation duplicates produced from the original data collected by sensors during an observation flight. The State Party requesting copies shall also notify the observed Party. A request for duplicates of data shall include the following information:</P>
<P class="p243 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(A)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft58">the observing Party;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p212 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(B)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">the observed Party;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p206 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(C)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">the date of the observation flight;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p206 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(D)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft58">the sensor by which the data was collected;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p181 ft14"><SPAN class="ft3">(E)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft44">the portion or portions of the observation period during which the data was collected; and</SPAN></P>
<P class="p181 ft10"><SPAN class="ft3">(F)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft9">the type and format of duplicate recording medium, either negative or positive film, or magnetic tape.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p244 ft24">Article X</P>
<P class="p245 ft56">OPEN SKIES CONSULTATIVE COMMISSION</P>
<P class="p246 ft14"><SPAN class="ft5">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft42">In order to promote the objectives and facilitate the implementation of the provisions of this Treaty, the States Parties hereby establish an Open Skies Consultative Commission.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p41 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft48">The Open Skies Consultative Commission shall take decisions or make recommendations by consensus. Consensus shall be understood to mean the absence of any objection by any State Party to the taking of a decision or the making of a recommendation.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p129 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft40">Each State Party shall have the right to raise before the Open Skies</SPAN></P>
<P class="p12 ft3">Consultative Commission, and have placed on its agenda, any issue rela-</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="id_2">
<P class="p12 ft3">Prop. 2001/02:157</P>
<P class="p12 ft3">Bilaga 6</P>
<P class="p118 ft3">60</P>
</DIV>
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_61">


<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t5">
<TR>
	<TD class="tr9 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">ting to this Treaty, including any issue related to the case when the ob-</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr9 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft5">Prop. 2001/02:157</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr7 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">served Party provides an observation aircraft.</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr7 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">Bilaga 6</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P class="p22 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft40">Within the framework of the Open Skies Consultative Commission the States Parties to this Treaty shall:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p174 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(A)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft58">consider questions relating to compliance with the provisions of this Treaty;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p247 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(B)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">seek to resolve ambiguities and differences of interpretation that may become apparent in the way this Treaty is implemented;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p174 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(C)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">consider and take decisions on applications for accession to this Treaty; and</SPAN></P>
<P class="p174 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(D)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft58">agree as to those technical and administrative measures, pursuant to the provisions of this Treaty, deemed necessary following the accession to this Treaty by other States.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p85 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">5.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft66">The Open Skies Consultative Commission may propose amendments to this Treaty for consideration and approval in accordance with Article XVI. The Open Skies Consultative Commission may also agree on improvements to the viability and effectiveness of this Treaty, consistent with its provisions. Improvements relating only to modification of the annual distribution of active quotas pursuant to Article III and Annex A, to updates and additions to the categories or capabilities of sensors pursuant to Article IV, to revision of the share of costs pursuant to Annex L, Section I, paragraph 9, to arrangements for the sharing and availability of data pursuant to Article IX, Sections III and IV and to the handling of mission reports pursuant to Article VI, Section I, paragraph 21, as well as to minor matters of an administrative or technical nature, shall be agreed upon within the Open Skies Consultative Commission and shall not be deemed to be amendments to this Treaty.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p24 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">6.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft7">The Open Skies Consultative Commission shall request the use of the facilities and administrative support of the Conflict Prevention Centre of the Conference on Security and </SPAN><NOBR>Co-operation</NOBR> in Europe, or other existing facilities in Vienna, unless it decides otherwise.</P>
<P class="p48 ft10"><SPAN class="ft5">7.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft50">Provisions for the operation of the Open Skies Consultative Commission are set forth in Annex L to this Treaty.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p231 ft24">Article XI</P>
<P class="p248 ft56">NOTIFICATIONS AND REPORTS</P>
<P class="p84 ft3">The States Parties shall transmit notifications and reports required by this Treaty in written form. The States Parties shall transmit such notifications and reports through diplomatic channels or, at their choice, through other official channels, such as the communications network of the Conference on Security and <NOBR>Co-operation</NOBR> in Europe.</P>
<P class="p249 ft24">Article XII</P>
<P class="p250 ft56">LIABILITY</P>
<P class="p226 ft3">A State Party shall, in accordance with international law and practice, be</P>
<P class="p49 ft54">liable to pay compensation for damage to other States Parties, or to their</P>
<P class="p215 ft3">61</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_62">


<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t5">
<TR>
	<TD class="tr9 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">natural or juridical persons or their property, caused by it in the course of</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr9 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft5">Prop. 2001/02:157</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr8 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">the implementation of this Treaty.</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr8 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">Bilaga 6</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P class="p224 ft24">Article XIII</P>
<P class="p251 ft56">DESIGNATION OF PERSONNEL AND PRIVILEGES AND</P>
<P class="p252 ft56">IMMUNITIES</P>
<P class="p226 ft3">SECTION I. DESIGNATION OF PERSONNEL</P>
<P class="p214 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft7">Each State Party shall, at the same time that it deposits its instrument of ratification to either of the Depositaries, provide to all other States Parties, for their review, a list of designated personnel who will carry out all duties relating to the conduct of observation flights for that State Party, including monitoring the processing of the sensor output. No such list of designated personnel shall include more than 400 individuals at any time. It shall contain the name, gender, date of birth, place of birth, passport number, and function for each individual included. Each State Party shall have the right to amend its list of designated personnel until 30 days after entry into force of this Treaty and once every six months thereafter.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p23 ft5"><SPAN class="ft5">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft67">In the event that any individual included on the original or any amended list is unacceptable to a State Party reviewing the list, that State Party shall, no later than 30 days after receipt of each list, notify the State Party providing that list that such individual shall not be accepted with respect to the objecting State Party. Individuals not declared unacceptable within that 30 day period shall be deemed accepted. In the event that a State Party subsequently determines that an individual is unacceptable, that State Party shall so notify the State Party that designated such individual. Individuals who are declared unacceptable shall be removed from the list previously submitted to the objecting State Party.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p47 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft40">The observed Party shall provide visas and any other documents as required to ensure that each accepted individual may enter and remain on the territory of that State Party for the purpose of carrying out duties relating to the conduct of observation flights, including monitoring the processing of the sensor output. Such visas and any other necessary documents shall be provided either:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p167 ft14"><SPAN class="ft3">(A)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft59">no later than 30 days after the individual is deemed to be accepted, in which case the visa shall be valid for a period of no less than 24 months; or</SPAN></P>
<P class="p174 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(B)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">no later than one hour after the arrival of the individual at the point of entry, in which case the visa shall be valid for the duration of that individual's duties; or</SPAN></P>
<P class="p174 ft10"><SPAN class="ft3">(C)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft68">at any other time, by mutual agreement of the States Parties involved.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p79 ft3">SECTION II. PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES</P>
<P class="p253 ft3">1. In order to exercise their functions effectively, for the purpose of</P>
<P class="p49 ft69">implementing this Treaty and not for their personal benefit, personnel</P>
<P class="p215 ft3">62</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_63">


<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t5">
<TR>
	<TD class="tr9 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">designated in accordance with the provisions of Section I, paragraph 1 of</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr9 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft5">Prop. 2001/02:157</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr6 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">this Article shall be accorded the privileges and immunities enjoyed by</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr6 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">Bilaga 6</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr6 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">diplomatic agents pursuant to Article 29; Article 30, paragraph 2; Article</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr6 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr6 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">31, paragraphs 1, 2 and 3; and Articles 34 and 35 of the Vienna Conven-</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr6 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr7 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">tion on Diplomatic Relations of 18 April 1961, hereinafter referred to as</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr7 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr6 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">the Vienna Convention. In addition, designated personnel shall be accor-</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr6 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr6 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">ded the privileges enjoyed by diplomatic agents pursuant to Article 36,</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr6 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr6 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">paragraph 1, subparagraph (b) of the Vienna Convention, except in rela-</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr6 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr6 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">tion to articles, the import or export of which is prohibited by law or con-</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr6 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr7 td18"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">trolled by quarantine regulations.</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr7 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P class="p85 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft43">Such privileges and immunities shall be accorded to designated personnel for the entire period between arrival on and departure from the territory of the observed Party, and thereafter with respect to acts previously performed in the exercise of their official functions. Such personnel shall also, when transiting the territory of other States Parties, be accorded the privileges and immunities enjoyed by diplomatic agents pursuant to Article 40, paragraph 1 of the Vienna Convention.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft48">The immunity from jurisdiction may be waived by the observing Party in those cases when it would impede the course of justice and can be waived without prejudice to this Treaty. The immunity of personnel who are not nationals of the observing Party may be waived only by the States Parties of which such personnel are nationals. Waiver must always be express.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p85 ft14"><SPAN class="ft5">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft44">Without prejudice to their privileges and immunities or the rights of the observing Party set forth in this Treaty, it is the duty of designated personnel to respect the laws and regulations of the observed Party.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft14"><SPAN class="ft5">5.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft49">The transportation means of the personnel shall be accorded the same immunities from search, requisition, attachment or execution as those of a diplomatic mission pursuant to Article 22, paragraph 3 of the Vienna Convention, except as otherwise provided for in this Treaty.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p254 ft24">Article XIV</P>
<P class="p255 ft56">BENELUX</P>
<P class="p178 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft7">Solely for the purposes of Articles II to IX and Article XI, and of Annexes A to I and Annex K to this Treaty, the Kingdom of Belgium, the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, and the Kingdom of the Netherlands shall be deemed a single State Party, hereinafter referred to as the Benelux.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p47 ft14"><SPAN class="ft5">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft70">Without prejudice to the provisions of Article XV, the abovementioned States Parties may terminate this arrangement by notifying all other States Parties thereof. This arrangement shall be deemed to be terminated on the next 31 December following the </SPAN><NOBR>60-day</NOBR> period after such notification.</P>
<P class="p256 ft3">63</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_64">


<DIV>
<DIV id="id_1">
<P class="p257 ft24">Article XV</P>
<P class="p258 ft56">DURATION AND WITHDRAWAL</P>
<P class="p259 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">This Treaty shall be of unlimited duration.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p199 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft48">A State Party shall have the right to withdraw from this Treaty. A State Party intending to withdraw shall provide notice of its decision to withdraw to either Depositary at least six months in advance of the date of its intended withdrawal and to all other States Parties. The Depositaries shall promptly inform all other States Parties of such notice.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p199 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft48">In the event that a State Party provides notice of its decision to withdraw from this Treaty in accordance with paragraph 2 of this Article, the Depositaries shall convene a conference of the States Parties no less than 30 days and no more than 60 days after they have received such notice, in order to consider the effect of the withdrawal on this Treaty.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p260 ft24">Article XVI</P>
<P class="p261 ft56">AMENDMENTS AND PERIODIC REVIEW</P>
<P class="p262 ft5"><SPAN class="ft5">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft57">Each State Party shall have the right to propose amendments to this Treaty. The text of each proposed amendment shall be submitted to either Depositary, which shall circulate it to all States Parties for consideration. If so requested by no less than three States Parties within a period of 90 days after circulation of the proposed amendment, the Depositaries shall convene a conference of the States Parties to consider the proposed amendment. Such a conference shall open no earlier than 30 days and no later than 60 days after receipt of the third of such requests.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p199 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft40">An amendment to this Treaty shall be subject to the approval of all States Parties, either by providing notification, in writing, of their approval to a Depositary within a period of 90 days after circulation of the proposed amendment, or by expressing their approval at a conference convened in accordance with paragraph 1 of this Article. An amendment so approved shall be subject to ratification in accordance with the provisions of Article XVII, paragraph 1, and shall enter into force 60 days after the deposit of instruments of ratification by the States Parties.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p182 ft14"><SPAN class="ft5">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft44">Unless requested to do so earlier by no less than three States Parties, the Depositaries shall convene a conference of the States Parties to review the implementation of this Treaty three years after entry into force of this Treaty and at </SPAN><NOBR>five-year</NOBR> intervals thereafter.</P>
<P class="p263 ft24">Article XVII</P>
<P class="p264 ft56">DEPOSITARIES, ENTRY INTO FORCE AND ACCESSION</P>
<P class="p265 ft31">1. This Treaty shall be subject to ratification by each State Party in accordance with its constitutional procedures. Instruments of ratification and instruments of accession shall be deposited with the Government of Canada or the Government of the Republic of Hungary or both, hereby designated the Depositaries. This Treaty shall be registered by the Depositaries pursuant to Article 102 of the Charter of the United Nations.</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="id_2">
<P class="p12 ft3">Prop. 2001/02:157</P>
<P class="p12 ft3">Bilaga 6</P>
<P class="p118 ft3">64</P>
</DIV>
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_65">


<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t5">
<TR>
	<TD class="tr9 td18"><SPAN class="p75 ft3">2. This Treaty shall enter into force 60 days after the deposit of 20 in-</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr9 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft5">Prop. 2001/02:157</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr6 td18"><SPAN class="p75 ft5">struments of ratification, including those of the Depositaries, and of Sta-</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr6 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">Bilaga 6</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr6 td18"><SPAN class="p75 ft3">tes Parties whose individual allocation of passive quotas as set forth in</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr6 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr7 td18"><SPAN class="p266 ft5">Annex A is eight or more.</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr7 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P class="p22 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft48">This Treaty shall be open for signature by Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Kazakhstan, Kirgistan, Moldova, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan and shall be subject to ratification by them. Any of these States which do not sign this Treaty before it enters into force in accordance with the provisions of paragraph 2 of this Article may accede to it at any time by depositing an instrument of accession with one of the Depositaries.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">4.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft40">For six months after entry into force of this Treaty, any other State participating in the Conference on Security and Co operation in Europe may apply for accession by submitting a written request to one of the Depositaries. The Depositary receiving such a request shall circulate it promptly to all States Parties. The States applying for accession to this Treaty may also, if they so wish, request an allocation of a passive quota and the level of this quota.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft14">The matter shall be considered at the next regular meeting of the Open Skies Consultative Commission and decided in due course.</P>
<P class="p22 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">5.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft40">Following six months after entry into force of this Treaty, the Open Skies Consultative Commission may consider the accession to this Treaty of any State which, in the judgement of the Commission, is able and willing to contribute to the objectives of this Treaty.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">6.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft40">For any State which has not deposited an instrument of ratification by the time of entry into force, but which subsequently ratifies or accedes to this Treaty, this Treaty shall enter into force 60 days after the date of deposit of its instrument of ratification or accession.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p88 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">7.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">The Depositaries shall promptly inform all States Parties of:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p174 ft14"><SPAN class="ft3">(A)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft59">the date of deposit of each instrument of ratification and the date of entry into force of this Treaty;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p174 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(B)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">the date of an application for accession, the name of the requesting State and the result of the procedure;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p174 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(C)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">the date of deposit of each instrument of accession and the date of entry into force of this Treaty for each State that subsequently accedes to it;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p175 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(D)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft58">the convening of a conference pursuant to Articles XV and XVI;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p174 ft14"><SPAN class="ft3">(E)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft44">any withdrawal in accordance with Article XV and its effective date;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p174 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(F)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft40">the date of entry into force of any amendments to this Treaty; and</SPAN></P>
<P class="p174 ft10"><SPAN class="ft3">(G)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft71">any other matters of which the Depositaries are required by this Treaty to inform the States Parties.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p267 ft3">65</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_66">


<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t14">
<TR>
	<TD class="tr16 td38"><SPAN class="p3 ft24">Article XVIII</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr16 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft5">Prop. 2001/02:157</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr26 td38"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr26 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft54">Bilaga 6</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P class="p268 ft56">PROVISIONAL APPLICATION AND PHASING OF IMPLEMENTATION OF THE TREATY</P>
<P class="p269 ft14">In order to facilitate the implementation of this Treaty, certain of its provisions shall be provisionally applied and others shall be implemented in phases.</P>
<P class="p270 ft3">SECTION I. PROVISIONAL APPLICATION</P>
<P class="p193 ft14"><SPAN class="ft5">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft42">Without detriment to Article XVII, the signatory States shall provisionally apply the following provisions of this Treaty:</SPAN></P>
<P class="p175 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(A)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft58">Article VI, Section I, paragraph 4;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p175 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(B)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">Article X, paragraphs 1, 2, 3, 6 and 7;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p175 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(C)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft32">Article XI;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p175 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(D)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft58">Article XIII, Section I, paragraphs 1 and 2;</SPAN></P>
<P class="p175 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(E)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft43">Article XIV; and</SPAN></P>
<P class="p175 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(F)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft40">Annex L, Section I.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p85 ft5"><SPAN class="ft5">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft67">This provisional application shall be effective for a period of 12 months from the date when this Treaty is opened for signature. In the event that this Treaty does not enter into force before the period of provisional application expires, that period may be extended if all the signatory States so decide. The period of provisional application shall in any event terminate when this Treaty enters into force. However, the States Parties may then decide to extend the period of provisional application in respect of signatory States that have not ratified this Treaty.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p271 ft3">SECTION II. PHASING OF IMPLEMENTATION</P>
<P class="p214 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">1.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft43">After entry into force, this Treaty shall be implemented in phases in accordance with the provisions set forth in this Section. The provisions of paragraphs 2 to 6 of this Section shall apply during the period from entry into force of this Treaty until 31 December of the third year following the year during which entry into force takes place.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">2.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft40">Notwithstanding the provisions of Article IV, paragraph 1, no State Party shall during the period specified in paragraph 1 above use an infrared </SPAN><NOBR>line-scanning</NOBR> device if one is installed on an observation aircraft, unless otherwise agreed between the observing and observed Parties. Such sensors shall not be subject to certification in accordance with An- nex D. If it is difficult to remove such sensor from the observation aircraft, then it shall have covers or other devices that inhibit its operation in accordance with the provisions of Article IV, paragraph 4 during the conduct of observation flights.</P>
<P class="p24 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">3.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft40">Notwithstanding the provisions of Article IV, paragraph 9, no State Party shall, during the period specified in paragraph 1 of this Section, be obliged to provide an observation aircraft equipped with sensors from each sensor category, at the maximum capability and in the numbers specified in Article IV,</SPAN></P>
<P class="p272 ft3">paragraph 2, provided that the observation aircraft is equipped with:</P>
<P class="p175 ft3"><SPAN class="ft3">(A)</SPAN><SPAN class="ft58">a single optical panoramic camera; or</SPAN></P>
<P class="p215 ft3">66</P>
</DIV>
<DIV id="page_67">


<TABLE cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 class="t5">
<TR>
	<TD class="tr9 td18"><SPAN class="p273 ft3">(B) not less than a pair of optical framing cameras.</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr9 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft5">Prop. 2001/02:157</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr6 td18"><SPAN class="p75 ft3">4. Notwithstanding the provisions of Annex B, Section II, paragraph 2,</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr6 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft3">Bilaga 6</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr6 td18"><SPAN class="p75 ft3">subparagraph (A) to this Treaty, data recording media shall be annotated</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr6 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr6 td18"><SPAN class="p75 ft5">with data in accordance with existing practice of States Parties during the</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr6 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
<TR>
	<TD class="tr7 td18"><SPAN class="p274 ft5">period specified in paragraph 1 of this Section.</SPAN> </TD>
	<TD class="tr7 td15"><SPAN class="p3 ft2">&nbsp;</SPAN> </TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P class="p22 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">5.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft43">Notwithstanding the provisions of Article VI, Section I, paragraph 1, no State Party during the period specified in paragraph 1 of this Section shall have the right to be provided with an aircraft capable of achieving any specified unrefuelled range.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft3"><SPAN class="ft5">6.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft43">During the period specified in paragraph 1 of this Section, the distribution of active quotas shall be established in accordance with the provisions of Annex A, Section II, paragraph 2 to this Treaty.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p22 ft14"><SPAN class="ft5">7.</SPAN><SPAN class="ft44">Further phasing in respect of the introduction of additional categories of sensors or improvements to the capabilities of existing categories of sensors shall be addressed by the Open Skies Consultative Commission in accordance with the provisions of Article IV, paragraph 3 concerning such introduction or improvement.</SPAN></P>
<P class="p224 ft24">Article XIX</P>
<P class="p275 ft56">AUTHENTIC TEXTS</P>
<P class="p276 ft14">The originals of this Treaty, of which the English, French, German, Italian, Russian and Spanish texts are equally authentic, shall be deposited in the archives of the Depositaries. Duly certified copies of this Treaty shall be transmitted by the Depositaries to all the States Parties.</P>
<P class="p277 ft24">ANNEX A</P>
<P class="p278 ft56">QUOTAS AND MAXIMUM FLIGHT DISTANCES</P>
<P class="p126 ft3">SECTION I. ALLOCATION OF PASSIVE QUOTAS</P>
